number of helpful: 4 of 13 people (31%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												Bought this game because it was for sale, very glad it was only 4 bucks, otherwise I would've returned it immediately after the first level. The controls suck and aren't very customizable like in UT2004. Ex. Can't use tab key to hotkey a weapon, in my case I used the tab key to quickly switch to the flak cannon, now I cannot even bind anything to it. Ex2. Using the translocator has become cumbersome whereas in the past it was easy to quickly switch back and forth between weapons by pressing the right and left mouse button in quick sucession, that was removed in this case. Also there is no more translocator camera where you could hit Q a second time to view exactly where the translocator was landing, which would give more of a flow. Ex3. Double jumping and wall dodges seem useless now, you don't cover a large distance as fast as you could in UT2004. I played UT2004 religiously in the past and got really really good at it to a point where I'd be accused of aimbotting and banned from multiple servers. This game was created for the casual FPS gamer whose used to slower arena fights like Halo and COD (I like those games but seriously just watch a Quakecon tournament and you'll see what "real" FPS shooters are)4/10 graphics are nice but the music and map selection also suck

content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												Okay here's an honest review:I gotta give this one a big "NO". Not because I think it's a bad game. It looks good. And I'm sure the UT purists out there hate it for it's lousy Console-to-PC port. I can't say I blame them. But it's definitely not an unplayable game, as far as multiplayer mode goes. The big problem with UT3 is there are no players playing it. So what you're left with is a morsel of servers, with a few players here or there. But no real community behind it. It's a sad thing to see.Aside from that mess, the singleplayer experience is dreadful. A very boring campaign mode. It's lack luster at best, I always felt the single player modes in the UT series were unnecessary to begin with. I always skip right over them to play the multiplayer game.Anyways, it's quite unforunate to see what happened to this series. Here's hoping Epic fixes things for UT4. I just can't reccommend this game to anyone.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												Pretty meh compared to the earlier games. I suggest getting the original or UT2004 instead.The environments are all bland and gray/brown now. Your character feels a lot heavier. Onslaught has been replaced with Warfare. It's generally the same, but it has this strange system where you can instacap a node using a special power orb. It completely ruins the mechanics of whittling down a node until it falls, and then rebuild it for your own team. It's all about rushing the orb ASAP. Campaign is not as good as the typical tournaments were. The new lore about respawners and them being powered by flags (CTF) is just stupid.Overall, it's kinda fun, but also kinda dead. Get UT2004 instead, you will not regret it.

number of helpful: 3 of 12 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												As fun as this game is, I just cannot see a reason to recommend this in a world where UT2004 exists.The previous iteration in the Unreal Tournament franchise has a better selection of modes, with assault, bombing run, and double domination all included, while the only truly new one to UT3 is vehicle CTF. UT3 also has betrayal and greed, but both are just variations on deathmatch for the most part.The weapon selection is fine, I personally miss the ripper and lightning gun, but its not that big of a deal. The updated graphics are quite nice, as well as the new vehicles and an actual story of some sort, but the lack of Assault mode is killer, and Bombing Run was a very fun introduction in UT2004 that sadly didn't make it here.Do yourself a favor and buy UT2004, it's a truly great game. This game isn't bad by any means, but it is lacking a lot of what it's predecessor brought to the table without much in the way of innovation to replace it.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												The Black Edition of Unreal Tournament 3 adds much needed new maps and gamemodes to add more content and is the definitive version of Unreal Tournament 3. UT3 is often forgotten and when it's not, people criticize it as being the worst Unreal Tournament game. Well, they're right. The games campaign is absolutely atrocious. Instead of the idea of the tournaments like in the other games and the managing that made UT2K4's single-player tournament ladder so fun, we instead have an actual story in which there's a war between the Necris and humans or something like that. It's absolutely forgettable and the way it tries to tie itself into the idea of respawning and doing things like Capture the Flag in a fully fledged war is just hilarious. It also features surprisingly atrocious acting (not exaggerating) and some of the worst writing I've seen in a game. The Unreal Tournament games had cheesy dialogue on purpose but when this takes itself so seriously it's just really hard to watch. The main issue with the game however is how heavy and weighty the movement is in this game. UT'99 and UT2K4 had fluid movement, which was needed for a fast paced arena game, but this along with muddy, bland graphics just makes it a game to skip and absolutely unnecessary when there are two far superior games and an incredible single-player focussed game, the original Unreal.Pros:+Music features some nice reinditions of UT99 classics+Sound effects are meaty, very well done+Fantastic particle effects+Vast amount of graphical setting options+Weapon array is nice as usual+Character customization is neat+Good atmosphere+New vehicles are awesome+Vehicles handle well+Onslaught is much improved from UT2K4'sCons:-Voice-acting goes beyond cheesy-Campaign should be skipped-Though music is good, there's a lack of new stuff-Graphics are bland and ugly despite having decent textures-Heavy feeling movement is a big negative in a game like this-Controller support leaves more to be desired-Less maps and gamemodes than the UT'99 and UT2K4-Characters all look big bulky and generic and aren't faithful to original designs-AI still hasn't been all that improved-Less mutators-No tournament style campaign like UT2K4-No people playing...never wereSound: 8/10Graphics: 4.5/10 Gameplay: 7/10Content/Replayability: 7/10Overall: 5.5/10I recommend UT3 if you're going to play as on easier difficulties to just mince some people, but there's no use spending time to relearn mechanics to play on harder difficulties if you played the others. Just skip it. Worse in most ways to its predecessors.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												Of all of the UT games made after 99, this might be the least bad.The gameplay is sub par, but it is a lot easier to get 10 people to download UT 3 off steam than it is to hand out UT99 CDs.  Actually that's not true; we had a bunch of authentication problems playing UT 3 on a LAN even though we all purchased it.The game DOES have a sniper rifle, and does NOT have that stupid♥♥♥♥♥lightning gun, so that's a huge plus.The rocket launcher's alternate fire only fires 3 rockets.  The only weapon with a lamer alt fire is the bio rifle.There are some classic maps which cool improvements, like Deck 17 and Facing Worlds.The single player campain is incredibly annoying.  Plotwise, they try to sort of invent this unecessary, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ story backwards from deathmatch to explain people dying and respawning all the time.  It seems complately unrelated to the "plot" of UT99.  The worst, though, is that you can't choose to play only deathmatch levels and/or completely ignore certain game modes.For multiplayer, they also try to force you onto some lame social media thing (which does not connect to steam) in order to play with other people.  I wish I had known that before buying.  At the last lan party I attended, no one was able to connect this way, so we all opted to play in disconnected/offline mode or whatever they call it.  Unfortunately when you do that, there is no UI for changing your name; you have to open the console and type something every single time you join.  Also, so far, I haven't found a way to save your single player progress in offline mode.A lot of very simple configurations and settings that I took for granted have been removed.  For example:  you can't do random map rotations.  UT 99 had a simple checkbox that let you enable map rotation to avoid playing the same order every time, or disable for people who hate fun.  It does seem like they've opted to have "mutators" take the place of simple configuration options, and I don't have a strong opinion on that, but they didn't include a mutator to put the random map feature back.The bot skill levels are a little wacky.  "Skilled" level bots spend a lot of time standing in one place waiting to be shot.  That seems like something that maybe only the first bot level should do.There is some new war mode thing with spheres.  Its kind of cool, although the vehicles are pretty lame.  Especially the hover board.  And Assault is gone.

Posted: April 4, 2012
												Another underrated avant-garde game from the Unreal saga, but something that has been admitted by the Epic Games Inc. as 'neglected'. The graphics are comparable to what we suppose would be the graphics of 2020, with additional applicable 3D options to enhance the experience. The issue that this game states is that 'feel' that unearthed when roaming UT2004; those options of being able to control the arena are lost, and the ability of the player degraded (I've certainly found that the 'Experienced' level on this is in some way harder than the 'Skilled' options of its direct predecessor (equivalent level 3 and 4 respectively). Notwithstanding, it is a credit to the Unreal series, and deserves to be pursued in future. It has set the precedent.

Posted: October 12, 2016
												All those positive recommends be like "good game, no players, but buy it!" Come on, really? What kind of logic is that?I can understand only nostalgic value of purchase of this game, because honestly, this game sucks on many points of view and I would bore you to death if I try to list and explain them all. The main critics points would be slower pace than its' predecessors', less game modes and ultimately bad visual design with overbloomed flavour. Yes, it is fun to play ONS/WAR mode, mainly due to necris vehicles, but you need actual players to play it, and if hardly anyone plays it, then what's the point of purchase? A singleplayer campaign, which is exactly a squence of bot matches with uneven odds? Dozens of empty servers with minimal bot count set to 4-6? Frustratingly dumb but accurate bots? All this dancing around game account, logins and CD keys? Don't lie to yourselves, this isn't the game you would actively play. Get it only for collection and nostalgia, but don't hope for a really great match.

Posted: February 22, 2014
												The super-rifle servers in Unreal Tournament have always been a sort of Valhalla for veteran FPS players. You typically spawn surrounded by every weapon available in the map, and it rarely takes longer than 2 seconds to find yourself in combat. The gravity is low, the speed is high, and the maps are enormous. One would expect things to degenerate into a lacksidasical camp-fest, but victory and a huge pile of enemy heads usually fall to those who fight like true warriors: the lightnight-fast, strafe-jumping, run-and-gunners. The only problem with this game is that there are not enough people playing it, and this is truly a sad thing, since the next best thing, Quake 3, pales in comparison to the frenetic insanity that is the standard in UT super-rifle servers.

Posted: June 26, 2015
												I've been a fan of the Unreal series since the original Unreal, but i find UT3 to be the most disappointing of them all (yes, i liked Unreal 2 more).I hate how consolized the menu is, i hate how Epic tried to pander to the Gears of War fans with those bulky and incredibly ugly player models that all look the same, i hate how all the maps have been "modernized" by removing colors and making everything grey & bloom, and i hate how they scrapped the single player tournament, a feature which i personally loved especially after how awesome and interactive they made it in UT2004, and replaced it with a generic war story i could have found in any other action game.However, UT3 has a redeeming factor: the modding. Just like in the previous games, you can download new and interesting player models made by the community, or even some older ones from the previous games. As always you can download hundreds of interesting maps ranging from the silly ones and giant rooms to classic remakes to the more impressive well-done maps. Mutators and total conversions are also still available, my favourite one being The Crucible, although many good ones from the past like ChaosUT and Ballistic unfortunately didn't go beyond demo stages.To top it all off, you can replace the whole menu with one worthy of a PC game by using the MapMixer mod. I especially like how it also lets you "clone" bots to customize and rename them, a feature which hasn't been around since UT99. If you're like me and still hold a grudge on the art style direction they took with UT3, the ability to block off GoW bots and default maps from ever being played is also quite nice.I can't say anything about the online aspect because i haven't been able to find any servers, possibly due to my game's settings not wanting to work.All in all i still recommend this game to UT fans, but only if you're planning to download custom content for it. And if you're not a UT fan, i suggest checking out UT99 and UT2004 first.

Posted: November 19, 2010
												Unreal has a varied and rich history dating back to early gaming on home computers, like the x486. This particular iteration has fantastic graphics, and fun gameplay in a deathmatch VS style setting. There's even a single player campaign in which you can guide your own course, and make your own decisions. Lots of fun weapons, some classics, a few new, and fun ways to combine primary and alternate fire. This game includes some new vehicles as well. I particuarly like the new tentacle style set, each with unique uses and functions you can maximize through strategic use. Like any deathamtch game, it's all about the maiming and killing, and full of gore, violence, and revenge for the 12 kills made on you by somone else.

Posted: April 21, 2012
												Bought this way back when it was released. Just started playing it again. It's too bad they tried to put a story on top of this game. It really kinda detracts from it.I've been a big fan of the Unreal series since the original UT way back in... 1997? And strictly speaking, this game should be titled UT4. But whatever. On with the review.Same gameplay you've come to expect from NotQuake. I've always felt that UT was a bit (not a lot) less twitchy than the Qake series. A bit more... gritty I guess. Quake for me was about the crazy maps, whereas UT has always been about the gameplay. This one doesn't add much to the gameplay, but it's a BIG facelift, and it doesn't add nothing. In place of the relocater, you sometimes get a hoverboard. And vehicles and turrets work much better than in previous titles.Controls are quite good, graphics are top shelf, weapons are interesting but easy to figure out. Gameplay modes are what have come to be standard. Again, the story is just stupid.If this was a movie, I'd be telling you it's so bad you have to see it. Unreal Tournament doesn't need a story, and actually suffers for having one. It's so stupid I don't even want to talk about it; I just want to ♥♥♥♥♥ about how mindless it is. Seriously, I will watch Go Fish: the Epic Miniseries before I sit through a cutscene or listen to a dialog in this game.

Posted: January 1, 2013
												Lots of fun, this pretty much a modern Quake III. It's what Nexuiz should have been, plus there's a campaign (although a bit bland). The strength is arena battles, which are very fast paced. The game features an array of gamemodes in both multiplayer and campaign, and they all have plentiful weapons that drop in a Quake-esque way. The framerates were high even at the highest settings (the menus had a lot of features to enable/disable), and that made it really easy to track and get kills without clientside lag.I found the way the campaign explained the respawn and weapon drops a little silly, it's generally better for it to remain a mystery unless your excuse is really good (looking at Assassin's Creed).If you liked Quake, get this game. If you were disappointed with Nexuiz, get this game. It's pretty cheap, and defiantly worth the money.

Posted: October 31, 2015
												While not as feature packed as its prior incarnation (UT 2004), UT3 is however one of the best "realistic looking" FPS games still available for purchase on the market (with the added bonus that its system requirements are now only a fraction of what modern dull looking FPS games demand), however the only thing lacking from UT3 is rebindable keys for gamepads (the game despite the lack of Steam store description has native support for the XBOX360 controller) but this is for most people a minor/non issue.At the time the Unreal games were so groundbreaking that even current FPS games are nothing other then a copy & paste affair in their feature (double jumps, power armor mechs in an FPS etc..) list; in fact I remember that when the original Unreal was released the 'Internets' and the ancient stone age technology known as BBS were full of people offering advice/guides (or begging for such advice/guides) on how to optimize their PC for Unreal, unsurprisingly when the original Unreal was released just like when the original Doom and Quake was released there was an upsurge in people getting new computers and/or upgrading their computers.  We owe a lot to these games as they were at the time the principal driving force behind the rapid processing power/technological advancement of household computers, it was also the principal cause of many young adults going bankrupt in the 90s.

Posted: February 22, 2014
												The super-rifle servers in Unreal Tournament have always been a sort of Valhalla for veteran FPS players. You typically spawn surrounded by every weapon available in the map, and it rarely takes longer than 2 seconds to find yourself in combat. The gravity is low, the speed is high, and the maps are enormous. One would expect things to degenerate into a lacksidasical camp-fest, but victory and a huge pile of enemy heads usually fall to those who fight like true warriors: the lightnight-fast, strafe-jumping, run-and-gunners. The only problem with this game is that there are not enough people playing it, and this is truly a sad thing, since the next best thing, Quake 3, pales in comparison to the frenetic insanity that is the standard in UT super-rifle servers.

Posted: April 5, 2015
												Most people play this in multiplayer mode.The storyline is about revenge for an ambush at the beginning of the game. You travel from location to location hunting down the one who took your squad down. In the end, you end up on her home world and are in a fight for your life. I had only wished they would have made an expansion for that cliffhanger ending.Story mode out of the way, you have the same Unreal game with major updates to just about everything.1. The graphics look outstanding. Even at fast speeds.2. The music is low key so it does not get in the way.3. Hover boards to fast travel. Not to mention other vehicles.4. Revised weapons. (however the ripper is not in this game)5. Levels are unique and look quite impressive.6. Online rooms & players are still plentifulIf you love NON-Realistic FPS games. Pick this one up. If you cannot handle teleporters, antigravity, etc go back to BF & COD. This game playes fast and furious, with campers getting killed real quicklike.

Posted: August 14, 2012
												I cant believe i havent recommended this one yet. Also it probably doesnt need one, its the church of PC FPS'ing. Anyone with a pc should really own a copy of one of the Unreal Tournements or the ... umm pc gamer fps police with come take ure pc away i guess. This is the latest instalment of the Unreal series and im starting to suspect it may be the last. Nexuiz is a more recent attempt to better this game but unfortunatly falls well short of the mark.  This style / genre of FPS's i believe are currently on a big downswing because of just how much people played this sort of thing back in the day. And now opt for more of the realist cover based / modern mockery shooters - not that theres anything wrong with that. But like the Unreal era i dont think it will last.Never the less its great, theres bugger all people playing multi, but the bots are still fun, its fast it flows and its generally fun in short bursts.

Posted: May 20, 2015
												Gorgeous game with great run and gun play. Has all the classic weapons you'd expect and they feel great, though the rocket launcher's different fire modes are needlessly complicated to switch. The flak cannon used to be my go-to UT weapon but the stinger mini-gun definitely takes the cake this time! There are some cool new gameplay modes and tons of fun maps but I do miss  the old Assault and Domination modes. The vehicles are really cool too! The single player campaign is a bit of a let down, the gameplay is really fun, but the story is hard to follow. A few characters seem cool but never get developed, the few cutscenes and mission briefing voiceovers do not effectively convey the story. It's a shame there weren't more teams/factions/clans introduced, and I was particularly bummed that the Skaarj didn't make an appearance. Character models sadly seemed more like Gears of War leftovers than of Unreal Tournament design. So while the sloppily thrown together single player campaign is a tad disappointing, the overall gameplay is still great fun and it looks great. More fun than UT2k3 and UT2k4!

												This game is fantastic still in 2015, but the multiplayer connectivity issues are a massive bummer. We've tried it all. Opening dozens of ports, disabling firewalls, running stunservers etc. Sometimes it works with one other player, sometimes with 2, and once you disconnect from a map it may stop working altogether, It's extremely random. Epic's refusal to address these widely reported issues is really quite shocking. Get this on sale only!

Posted: December 5, 2014
												Unreal Tournament has been a great series, including this game. The Action is fast paced and fluid with beautiful, yet smooth graphics. for a game made in 2007, it really puts other games to shame. There are plenty of Game Modes, Maps, and Settings that will keep its replay value high, even 7 years after its release. The ingame AI (Bots) play like a human so having good internet really isn't a huge requirement to fully enjoy this game. This game also comes with a Map Editor using the Unreal 3 Engine so you can make your ideas come to life. Like most other Unreal Games, this game has plenty of Mod Support.

Posted: April 4, 2012
												Another underrated avant-garde game from the Unreal saga, but something that has been admitted by the Epic Games Inc. as 'neglected'. The graphics are comparable to what we suppose would be the graphics of 2020, with additional applicable 3D options to enhance the experience. The issue that this game states is that 'feel' that unearthed when roaming UT2004; those options of being able to control the arena are lost, and the ability of the player degraded (I've certainly found that the 'Experienced' level on this is in some way harder than the 'Skilled' options of its direct predecessor (equivalent level 3 and 4 respectively). Notwithstanding, it is a credit to the Unreal series, and deserves to be pursued in future. It has set the precedent.

Posted: April 13, 2016
												The pros:It has all the great basics of Unreal: nice graphics, the classic Unreal series weaponry, and intense combat.The neutral:The general visual appearance is darker and gloomier than in the previous titles. I liked it, from the aesthetic point of view. In online matches, it might make it harder to spot your opponents, which I believe is the reason why some people complained about it.The cons:Even though single player has not been the main target in any of the Tournament series games, this does it worse than the previous titles. Forcibly introducing "respawners" and "FLaGs" into the original UT story was just lame. I'd rather have confronted Xan once more. Also, most characters look like they had been overdosing on steroids.Recommended? Yes and no. For hardcore fans of the Unreal series or the genre, why not. But if you're looking for a state-of-the-art online arena shooter, it's probably a better idea to get UT 4 right now. Even though it's still "pre-alpha", it probably has more online players than this, and it will do most things even better when it's complete.

People are just mad because the characters look straight outa Gears of War.Regarding play-style it's much like the original UT99 - faster than UT2k4, not as floaty as UT2k4 and not all hitscan.That being said, a new Unreal Tournament game is coming soon for free, so there's not much point in buying this  outside of the Unreal Deal Pack anymore (or any UT games for that matter).EDIT: You might want to play this instead of the new UT afterall... at least for now x)

Posted: November 19, 2010
												Unreal has a varied and rich history dating back to early gaming on home computers, like the x486. This particular iteration has fantastic graphics, and fun gameplay in a deathmatch VS style setting. There's even a single player campaign in which you can guide your own course, and make your own decisions. Lots of fun weapons, some classics, a few new, and fun ways to combine primary and alternate fire. This game includes some new vehicles as well. I particuarly like the new tentacle style set, each with unique uses and functions you can maximize through strategic use. Like any deathamtch game, it's all about the maiming and killing, and full of gore, violence, and revenge for the 12 kills made on you by somone else.

Posted: April 21, 2012
												Bought this way back when it was released. Just started playing it again. It's too bad they tried to put a story on top of this game. It really kinda detracts from it.I've been a big fan of the Unreal series since the original UT way back in... 1997? And strictly speaking, this game should be titled UT4. But whatever. On with the review.Same gameplay you've come to expect from NotQuake. I've always felt that UT was a bit (not a lot) less twitchy than the Qake series. A bit more... gritty I guess. Quake for me was about the crazy maps, whereas UT has always been about the gameplay. This one doesn't add much to the gameplay, but it's a BIG facelift, and it doesn't add nothing. In place of the relocater, you sometimes get a hoverboard. And vehicles and turrets work much better than in previous titles.Controls are quite good, graphics are top shelf, weapons are interesting but easy to figure out. Gameplay modes are what have come to be standard. Again, the story is just stupid.If this was a movie, I'd be telling you it's so bad you have to see it. Unreal Tournament doesn't need a story, and actually suffers for having one. It's so stupid I don't even want to talk about it; I just want to ♥♥♥♥♥ about how mindless it is. Seriously, I will watch Go Fish: the Epic Miniseries before I sit through a cutscene or listen to a dialog in this game.

Posted: November 18, 2013
												Wow... What a game this is! I sorely misunderstood it's strengths and underestimated this game for years. I've always tried to play through the single player campaign and always bounced right off it as that mode is genuinely terrible, repetitive and boring. However as I'll go onto explain, this was a mistake.Firstly, the reason for not enjoying the campaign mode is due to it focusing on the "Capture the Flag" and "Warfare" team modes. Capture the Flag (CTF) is a familair game type and Warfare is about Capturing Control Points which includes vehicles you can use to fight your battles along with the usual weapons. Warfare matches in particular are normally set on huge sprawling battle fields for it to take place across... so why is this terrible?It boils down to the Bot AI specifically for Warfare (CTF isn't too bad to be fair)... simple as that. They cannot play this team mode in any fun way and these long.. drawn out...  tug of war matches get mired in stalemate and boredom. There are only so many times you can spend minutes trekking across a huge map to be killed pointlessly and then respawn to do it again. With human teams, working together to co-ordinate attack and defence, I imagine it would be great... but the bots know nothing of a high strategy and the game degenerates into pockets of combat that just chew up and spit everyone out resulting in a grind. No flanking, feints, different paths of attack or even retreating, just running at each other, fighting, dying and doing it again which is ultimately what the player is drawn into as well. Awful...  and so UT3 was in my view the worst game of the series... UNTIL! I ignored the campaign mode and just worked through every available map via the Instant Action option (i.e. Custom Match Mode), sticking to the game types I enjoyed. Playing like this is BRILLIANT...  I played Deathmatch, Team Deathmatch, Greed ( a form of deathmatch CTF) and Instagib deathmatch (one hit kills) all on Adept difficulty and just ignored the other modes I didn't like or just weren't enjoyable to play with bots... and man alive what a game!The speed, the sound, the graphics, the weapons..  adept diffculty was the exact amount of challenge for me at the time of writing. Every match was an unknown and I never went into a game confident I'd win or sure I'd lose. UT3 is on par with the mighty UT 1999 (IMHO) when it comes to playing with bots on the main Deathmatch modes. It is great!I ended up playing 145 matches across those 4 modes on every map to eventually win them all, and that doesn't include the games I played on the campaign in co-op with Steam friends, or the experiments with some of the other modes like Betrayal or CTF. Truely an excellent game when you stick to it's strengths and I enjoyed "completing" the game per my own rules for doing so. I think making my own objectives within some games is going to breathe new life into them where I have stopped playing due to a lack of direction from the game or a terrible single player story / campaign mode. It's not something I have done before... as silly as that sounds, and I am glad I did here as it opened my eyes to an excellent game.Although I have completed my "Adept" run, I'll be trying again on harder difficulties and downloading user maps for sure. This game will likely stay on my hard drive for a long time and the "time played" (currently 35hrs) will increase beyond what is recorded here, just like UT 1999.

Posted: December 30, 2013
												Though I can't say that this is the best of the Unreal series, it's an incredibly fun game to play, online, or by yourself.The good? It's quite beautiful indeed, definitely a show of what the Unreal engine is capable of. The weapons are for the most part fun to use, all with a secondary mode that makes the battle more interesting. The AI on your team are always a little duller than the rest, so you're forced to join the carnage on a more tactical level.The bad? The campaign is a pretty average, as you would expect. The usual "you wronged us and now we're gonna go to great lengths to kill you even though it won't solve anything in the grand scheme of things" storyline. The AI tend to get stuck on each other (or snipe you with Enforcers from the other side of the map if you're giving Godlike a go), and great Scott, if you just add a chainsaw machine gun and a working cover system and you've got Gears of War. Seriously, the armour style, the main antagonist is some crazy chick who wants nothing but pain as far as the eye can see. And not to mention your stereotypical upbeat wise-crackin' black guy.I'd recommend this game to anyone interesting in the new and old takes on arena-style first-person shooters.

Posted: December 13, 2016
												get online and get playin people ,♥♥♥♥♥csgoUPDATEOk to get the best experience , if like me using 1080p tv , look wise, use nvidea control panel, set a DSR (dynamic super resolution) factor so that you can upscale to 4k IN THE GLOBAL SETTINGS......IN THE PROGRAM SETTINGS Find unreal tournement 3 exe, use Ambient Oclusion set that to quality with antisotropic filtering set to 16X.... FXAA off... AA mode 'Enhance the application setting' with x2, set transparnecy to 8x supersample (optitional is DSR doesnt work for you) , texture filtering set to high quality (cant tell if this makes a difference) but the rest of settings makes it look ♥♥♥♥ing stunning compared to 1920x1080 with nothing changed.. when in game you can change the resloution the DSR factors you choose at the nvidea control panel... awsome! feels like im playing a fresh game  ! ! finally for personal taste , in game menu , i set the FOV to med-high - gives realism to your movements, i do this with any title that supports it....BUT! That right there is where nvidea control panel really comes real handy, games of the last decade or so , na i guess even last 20 years,nvidea supported anyway ... online - there are people playing, not booming like bf1 servers no , but, the more people give it the hype that it well deserves then it would be as popular as csgo and can still well be........ so , the more people push for the hype in remebering just how gooood this game was and still is, blows cs go out of the fps water ! .  ive played unreal since the first in 97 98,, last time i played this version however was on a ps3 and CTF Vehical was the most addictive fun for me....  i recomend this to everyone , there are a many new generation of people that are not even aware that such fun even existed.. so lets push this out there abit and get the servers re populated! if they have done it with cs go..... then we can with this. very simplywhen in server browser.. set dedicated servers on and set it to find all games , you see maps that will have bots and online players...

Posted: January 15
												While the graphics aren't anything special now, you gotta remember that this was the first game that used the Unreal Engine 3, and at the time it dropped our jaws to the frikkin floor.The weapons and modes of the much beloved and excellent UT2004 return, along with a rudimentary campaign/ladder thing, yet the meat of the game lied in multiplayer. So, in short, this was everything that UT2004 was, but with much better graphics. Which is the puzzling thing: UT2004 was immensely popular. This one wasn't. It felt slightly clunkier. Slightly heavier. Slightly slower. Slightly less fun. Or maybe the world was fed up and/or saturated with online FPS games with otherworldly environments and weapons when it came out. Whatever the case, this was not very popular, and the years haven't been particularly kind to it and its playerbase online.That being said, for newcomers to the series, it's worth playing today, even if it is with bots, if only to familiarise yourself with the franchise till the new one is out properly.

Posted: January 16
												For the TlDR's..If your after some intense singleplayer jump right in fragfest with nice visuals get this game. the bots suit all levels of ability up to godlike players to casuals. dont expect much for multiplayer matches..  this games commonly on sale for £6 usually.. then its worth your money :) wouldnt recommend paying full price.I've played Unreal since UT99 GOTY And love the series. Pros-fast paced game play with favourite weapons from the old games-the graphics are amazing.. low end systems will easily get 100 fps on highest quality which is a massive bonus-bots are smart with massive variation in difficulty for new and veteran players-Lots of maps, game modes & mutators-single player campaign isnt too bad.-like the originals.. theres tons of community contentCons-warzone game mode is irritating and some what unplayable.. I didnt like warzone in earlier games so this isnt a big deal to me-multiplayer is dead.. if your looking for multiplayer UT, go for 99 2004 & the UT4 free alpha game on epics website-maps look visually pleasing but just lack pacing & gameplay quality to older games.
